author: Michael Roddan
title: We can clean up, says Yellow Brick Road executive chairman Mark Bouris
text:
YELLOW Brick Road executive chairman Mark Bouris says the group plans to capitalise on moves by the major banks to tighten lending for investment­ properties.
Mr Bouris said his company had been building its strategy and business model around such a shift in the market, although­ the shift had come earlier than expected.
Under pressure from the regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, major banks and other lenders have tightened access to investor loans, increasing interest rates and deposit ratios or, in the case of AMP Bank, temporarily withdrawing from the market.
The watchdog is trying to slow the growth in lending to investors to 10 per cent a year.
The Reserve Bank and APRA have been trying to soothe concerns of a speculative property bubble in Australian capital cities, fuelled by low interest rates and strong investor lending.
Mr Bouris said demand in Yellow Brick Road’s core owner-occupied market would strengthen as a result.
The company planned to support this with “highly competitive rates” and a high media profile over the coming year, he said. “The investor market will tighten but we are well positioned to compete for quality loans.”
It came as Yellow Brick Road declared it would post another full-year loss, but had lifted underlying earnings into the black for the first time.
The company said its net loss for the financial year just finished would be smaller than $1 million — an improvement from the previous year’s $8.8 million loss.
Underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation would clock in about $1 million, compared with a $5.2 million loss last year.
Yellow Brick Road has not posted a profit since listing on the sharemarket in 2007.
Shares in the group closed 2.5c higher at 49c.
 We can clean up, says Bouris
